chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Acute diverticulitis
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with acute diverticulitis in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 18 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with acute diverticulitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange urgent hospital admission for specialist investigations and management if there is suspected acute diverticulitis and the person:
    • Has a suspected complication, such as rectal bleeding that may require urgent blood transfusion; bowel perforation; peritonitis; or abscess.
    • Has symptoms such as severe abdominal pain which cannot be managed in primary care.
    • Is dehydrated or at risk of dehydration and is unable to take or tolerate oral fluids at home.
    • Is unable to take or tolerate oral antibiotics (if needed) at home.
    • Is frail and/or has significant co-morbidities and/or is immunocompromised (for example has diabetes mellitus, end-stage chronic kidney disease, malignancy, cirrhosis, or is taking immunosuppressive drugs).
  • Manage the person in primary care if there is suspected mild, uncomplicated diverticulitis, depending on clinical judgement:
    • Consider prescribing oral antibiotics if there is suspected infection.
      • If needed, prescribe at least 5 days of co-amoxiclav (or a combination of cefalexin with metronidazole or trimethoprim with metronidazole or ciprofloxacin and metronidazole if the person is allergic to penicillin).
      • See the sections on Co-amoxiclav, Cefalexin, Trimethoprim, Ciprofloxacin, and Metronidazole in Prescribing information for more information.
    • Consider watchful waiting if the person is systemically well, has no co-morbidities, and there is no suspected infection.
    • Advise on the use of analgesia, such as paracetamol as-needed.
      • Advise the person to avoid nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and opioid analgesia (such as codeine) if possible, due to the potential increased risk of diverticular perforation.
    • Recommend clear liquids only, with a gradual reintroduction of solid food if symptoms improve over the following 2–3 days.
    • Consider checking bloods for raised white cell count and C-reactive protein (CRP), which may suggest infection.
  • If the person is managed in primary care, arrange a review within 48 hours, or sooner if symptoms worsen.
    • Arrange urgent hospital admission if symptoms persist or deteriorate despite management in primary care.
  • Consider arranging referral to a specialist in colorectal surgery if a person is managed in primary care and has frequent or severe recurrent episodes of acute diverticulitis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Specialist investigations and management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Specialist investigations may include:

  • Ultrasound scan of the abdomen and pelvis.
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis to establish the diagnosis, determine the extent and severity of disease, and exclude any complications.
  • Urgent colonoscopy to establish the diagnosis and treat the source of bleeding if there is diverticular haemorrhage.
  • Planned colonoscopy or CT colonography in selected patients after resolution of acute complicated diverticulitis symptoms, to exclude alternative diagnoses such as inflammatory bowel disease, ischaemic colitis, or colorectal cancer.

Specialist management may include:

  • Intravenous antibiotics, fluid replacement, and analgesia.
  • Urgent surgery for people with acute complicated diverticulitis (for example with peritonitis and sepsis), and for people who do not improve with medical treatment. Surgical options include:
    • Percutaneous drainage of large abscesses.
    • Peritoneal lavage.
    • Simple colostomy formation.
    • Sigmoid resection with colostomy (Hartmann's procedure).
    • Sigmoid resection with a primary colocolic or colorectal anastomosis with or without a diverting colostomy or ileostomy.
  • Elective surgery may be considered for people with recurrent complicated diverticulitis (for example stricture or fistula formation) or immunocompromised people at high risk of complications.

[Wilkins, 2013; Morris, 2014; Strate, 2015; Humes, 2016; Sartelli, 2016; Tursi, 2016]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of acute diverticulitis are based on consensus opinion in the World Society of Emergency Surgery (WSES) Guidelines for the management of acute left sided colonic diverticulitis in the emergency setting [Sartelli, 2016], expert opinion in the American Gastroenterological Association (AGA) Institute Technical review on the management of acute diverticulitis [Strate, 2015], the American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons Practice parameters for the treatment of sigmoid diverticulitis [Feingold, 2014], the consensus statements International, expert-based, consensus statement regarding the management of acute diverticulitis [O'Leary, 2015] and Management of patients with diverticulosis and diverticular disease [Tursi, 2016], and expert opinion in the Association of Coloproctology of Great Britain and Ireland (ACPGBI) Commissioning guide: colonic diverticular disease [ACPGBI, 2014]. In addition, they are based on a Cochrane systematic review Antibiotics for uncomplicated diverticulitis [Shabanzadeh and Wille-Jørgensen, 2012] and systematic reviews of the use of antibiotics in uncomplicated diverticulitis [de Korte et al, 2011; Humes, 2016] and out-patient management of mild, uncomplicated diverticulitis [Balasubramanian, 2017], together with expert opinion in review articles on the diagnosis and management of acute diverticulitis [Salzman and Lillie, 2005; Wilkins, 2013; Morris, 2014; Bugiantella, 2015].

Arranging urgent hospital admission
  • The recommendations on when to arrange urgent admission are largely based on consensus opinion in the WSES guidelines [Sartelli, 2016] and expert opinion in review articles [Wilkins, 2013; Bugiantella, 2015].
    • People with co-morbidities and who are immunocompromised are at increased risk of complications such as perforation that may require emergency surgery, and are more likely to have a complicated recovery [Wilkins, 2013; Sartelli, 2016].
Prescribing oral antibiotics in primary care
  • The recommendations on prescribing oral antibiotics if there is suspected infection are based on consensus opinion in the WSES guidelines [Sartelli, 2016] and evidence in systematic reviews and expert opinion in review articles.
    • A systematic review of 10 retrospective studies (n = 772) of outpatient management of people with mild or uncomplicated diverticulitis found no difference in the failure rate of medical treatment or in recurrence rates between people receiving treatment in the community or as an inpatient. It concludes that antibiotic treatment in the community is a safe and viable option in selected people with uncomplicated diverticulitis. CKS notes, however, that all study participants had a diagnosis of uncomplicated diverticulitis confirmed by computed tomography (CT) imaging, and a meta-analysis of the data was not possible, due to heterogeneity in study designs and inclusion criteria [Balasubramanian, 2017].
    • Expert opinion in a review article on sigmoid diverticulitis cites evidence that there is no advantage of intravenous over oral antibiotics for selected people with acute diverticulitis [Morris, 2014].
    • The recommendations on antibiotic choice are based on the need to use broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover anaerobes and Gram-negative rods are extrapolated from the WSES guidelines [Sartelli, 2016] and expert opinion in a review article [Salzman and Lillie, 2005].
  • The choice of oral antibiotic is based on NICE NG147 Diverticular disease: diagnosis and management 2019 [NICE, 2019]. 
Considering watchful waiting
  • The recommendations on considering watchful waiting are based on consensus opinion in the WSES guidelines [Sartelli, 2016], the AGA Institute technical review [Strate, 2015], expert opinion in the ACPGBI commissioning guide [ACPGBI, 2014], and evidence in systematic reviews. Acute mild uncomplicated diverticulitis symptoms may be self-limiting and due to chronic inflammation, rather than infection of the colon, in immunocompetent people.
    • Consensus opinion in the WSES guidelines state that antibiotic therapy may not be needed in immunocompetent people with uncomplicated diverticulitis who have no signs of systemic infection, as this may be a self-limiting condition. If antibiotics are needed, oral drug treatment may be acceptable [Sartelli, 2016].
    • The AGA Institute technical review found low-quality evidence that antibiotics should be used selectively in people with acute uncomplicated diverticulitis. CKS notes that this recommendation was based on evidence from people with mild uncomplicated diverticulitis confirmed by radiological investigations, so these findings cannot be extrapolated to people who have a working diagnosis of acute diverticulitis based on clinical findings alone [Strate, 2015].
    • A Cochrane systematic review of three randomized controlled trials (RCTs) of antibiotic use in people with radiologically-confirmed left-sided uncomplicated diverticulitis, found there was no good-quality evidence to routinely support the use of antibiotics. CKS notes that a meta-analysis was not possible due to heterogeneity in interventions between the studies, and the risk of bias varied from low to high [Shabanzadeh and Wille-Jørgensen, 2012]. A systematic review of people with acute uncomplicated left-sided diverticulitis found the use of antibiotics had no effect on the complication rate, need for surgery, or recurrence rate [de Korte et al, 2011].
    • A systematic review of broad-spectrum antibiotics versus placebo or no treatment found very low-quality evidence that antibiotics were of unknown effectiveness in the treatment of acute uncomplicated diverticulitis, and concluded that in mild disease, antibiotic treatment may not be beneficial [Humes, 2016].
Advice on analgesia
  • The recommendations on analgesia are extrapolated from conflicting evidence in the literature on the safety of certain analgesics in the management of acute diverticulitis.
    • The AGA Institute technical review states there is uncertainty whether the regular use of aspirin or NSAIDs increases the risk of recurrent diverticulitis, complications, surgery, or abdominal pain, based on very low-quality evidence. It also cites evidence that opiate analgesia may increase the risk of perforated diverticulitis [Strate, 2015].
    • Expert opinion in a consensus document states that aspirin or NSAIDs may potentially increase the risk of diverticular complications [Tursi, 2016].
    • Expert opinion in a review article states that there is no evidence that aspirin, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or opiate analgesia has a negative effect on the course of an episode of acute diverticulitis, however the administration of NSAIDs at home may increase the risk of complicated diverticulitis [Bugiantella, 2015].
Advice on taking clear liquids only
  • The recommendation to advise a clear liquid diet until symptoms improve is based on expert opinion in a review article [Wilkins, 2013].
Considering checking bloods
  • The recommendation on checking inflammatory markers is based on consensus opinion in the WSES guidelines, which state that a raised white cell count or C-reactive protein (CRP) of 50 mg/L or more suggests a diagnosis of acute left-sided colonic diverticulitis, in association with typical clinical features [Sartelli, 2016].
  • This is supported by expert opinion in the AGA Institute technical review [Strate, 2015], an international consensus statement [O'Leary, 2015], and expert opinion in a review article on acute diverticulitis, which states that a raised white cell count is present in 55% of people with acute diverticulitis [Wilkins, 2013].
Arranging review within 48 hours
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in review articles [Wilkins, 2013; Bugiantella, 2015] and is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good medical practice.
Considering specialist referral for recurrent acute diverticulitis
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in the ACPGBI commissioning guide [ACPGBI, 2014] and is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good medical practice.
